  "article_text": [
    "fix @xmath0 a field of characteristic zero .",
    "a fundamental fact in mathematics is the existence of a functor @xmath1 from the category of sets into the category @xmath0-vector spaces .",
    "the functor @xmath2 sends a set @xmath3 into @xmath4 the free @xmath0-vector space generated by @xmath3 and sends a map @xmath5 into the linear transformation @xmath6 whose value on @xmath7 is @xmath8 . + it is important to notice that both @xmath9 and @xmath10 are symmetric monoidal categories with coproduct and that @xmath11 is a monoidal functor that respects coproducts .",
    "the monoidal structure on @xmath9 is cartesian product @xmath12 and the coproduct is disjoint union @xmath13 .",
    "the monoidal structure on @xmath10 is tensor product @xmath14 and the coproduct is direct sum @xmath15 .",
    "the restricted functor @xmath16 is such that the dimension @xmath17 of @xmath18 is the cardinality @xmath19 of @xmath3 for each @xmath3 in @xmath20 , the category of finite sets . + using @xmath11 we can transform ( combinatorial ) set theoretical notions into ( finite dimensional ) linear algebra notions . for example",
    "the linear analogue of a monoid is an associative algebra since for any monoid @xmath3 the vector space @xmath4 carries the structure of an associative algebra .",
    "similarly , the linear analogue of a group is a hopf algebra since @xmath4 carries a structure of a hopf algebra for any group @xmath3 .",
    "+ boolean algebras has been known since 1854 and are a cornerstone of modern mathematics . despite its widespread range of applications we believe the right name for boolean algebras should have been boolean monoids . for most mathematicians",
    "the word algebra implies a linear structure which is certainly not included in the traditional definition of boolean algebras . for the purposes of this paper we find useful to make the distinction between boolean monoids and boolean algebras",
    "the first goal of this paper is to uncover the linear analogue of boolean monoids , i.e. , we answer the question : what algebraic structure does @xmath4 carry for any boolean monoid @xmath3 ?",
    "we will see that there are an infinite number of non - isomorphic boolean algebras .",
    "+ the second goal of this paper is to study the symmetric powers of boolean algebras . we compute the structural constants of such algebras in various dimension , and show that each symmetric function can be use to formulate a generalization of the inclusion - exclusion principle for the symmetric powers of boolean algebra . our final goal is to propose a logical interpretation for boolean algebras and pose some open problems .",
    "we recall the definition of boolean monoids for definiteness and reader convenience , so that he or she may contrast it with the definition of boolean algebras given below .",

    "in this section we give a scientific explanation for our choice of axioms for boolean algebras .",
    "we do so by defining the prop in @xmath10 whose algebras are boolean algebras and showing that this prop actually comes from a prop in @xmath9 whose algebras are boolean monoids . discovering the prop that controls a given family of algebras is like unveiling its genetic code @xcite , @xcite , @xcite , @xcite , @xcite . despite the fact that boolean algebras have been extensively studied from a myriad of view points",
    "its genetic code has not been study so far .",
    "since the theory of props is not widely known we provide an overview using a convenient notation for our purposes .",

    "an element @xmath286 in the basis of @xmath217>^{\\otimes m}/s_{m}$ ] determines a vector @xmath299 .",
    "functions on @xmath300 are known as symmetric functions .",
    "there are many interesting examples of polynomial symmetric functions such as the power functions , the elementary symmetric functions , the homogeneous functions , the schur functions and so on .",
    "for example the polynomial @xmath301 is @xmath302-invariant .",
    "each symmetric function can be used to obtain a symmetric form of the inclusion - exclusion principle .",
    "the reader will find interesting information on the inclusion - exclusion principle and its generalizations in several papers by rota and his collaborators in @xcite .",
    "we use the inclusion - exclusion principle in the following form .    [ bit ]",
    "let @xmath303 then @xmath304}(-1)^{|i|+1}|\\bigcap_{i\\in i}a_{i}|.$ ]    we consider the symmetric inclusion - exclusion principles derived from the power , elementary , and homogeneous symmetric functions .",
    "other symmetric functions can be used as well but we shall not do so here .",
    "the power function @xmath305>^{\\otimes m}/s_{m } \\rightarrow \\mathbb{r}$ ] is given on the basis by @xmath306 we use the power functions @xmath307 to get a symmetric form of the inclusion - exclusion principle .",

    "theorem [ siep ] implies that    @xmath328^{2}+[\\mu(b)+\\mu(d)-\\mu(b\\cap d)]^{2}\\\\ & & + \\ \\ [ \\mu(a)+\\mu(d)-\\mu(a\\cap d)]^{2}+[\\mu(b)+\\mu(c)-\\mu(b\\cap c)]^{2}\\\\ & & + \\ \\ 2\\mu(a)\\mu(b)+2\\mu(c)\\mu(a)+\\mu(a)\\mu(d)+\\mu(c)\\mu(b)+\\mu(a)\\mu(c)\\\\ & & + \\ \\",

    "\\mu(c)\\mu(a\\cap d).\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]",
    "it is hard to do any work on boolean monoids and not to mention at all its relation with propositional logic . indeed the motivation of boole himself to introduce boolean monoids was to describe the mathematical structures that control the laws of though .",
    "propositional logic deals with the relation of deduction among sequences of sets of sentences constructed from a given finite set of propositions connected by a fixed set of connecting symbols .",
    "let us denote the set of given propositions @xmath59 and the set of sentences by @xmath329 .",
    "there are many ways to describe a system of propositional logic but in any of them one can imagine that there exists a sort of logical agent capable of performing the following tasks    * recognize when a grammatical construction is an element of @xmath329 .",
    "the agent is able to translate into sentences in @xmath329 expressions of the form @xmath330 , @xmath331 , and @xmath332 for sentences @xmath333 and @xmath44 in @xmath329 . *",
    "decide wether or not a sequence of sets of sentences @xmath334 is a deduction .",
    "* assign a truth value to each sentence in @xmath329 when provided with a assignment of truth values for propositions in @xmath108 , i.e. , an element of @xmath335 .",
    "+ a sentence @xmath333 is said to imply a sentence @xmath44 if there exists a deduction @xmath334 such that @xmath336 and @xmath337 .",
    "the logical operator is said to be sound and complete if the following property holds * sentence @xmath338 implies sentence @xmath339 if for any assignment of truth values to propositions in @xmath59 the truth value of @xmath44 is @xmath340 if the truth value of @xmath333 is @xmath340 .",
    "it is no hard to show the existence of sound a complete logical agents @xcite .",
    "boolean monoids appear within the context of propositional logic as follows .",
    "say that sentences @xmath333 and @xmath44 in @xmath329 are equivalent if @xmath333 implies @xmath44 and @xmath44 implies @xmath333 .",
    "let @xmath341 be the quotient of @xmath329 by this equivalence relation .",
    "@xmath341 comes equipped with a natural structure of boolean monoid with operations defined by @xmath342 \\cup[t]=[s \\vee t]$ ] , @xmath342 \\cup[t]=[s \\wedge t]$ ] , and @xmath342^c = [ -s]$ ] , for @xmath342 $ ] and @xmath343 $ ] in @xmath341 .",
    "the total element is @xmath344 $ ] and the empty element is @xmath345.$ ] the boolean monoid @xmath341 is isomorphic to the boolean monoid @xmath346 via the map @xmath347 sending each sentence @xmath342 \\in s$ ] into the set of its models @xmath348)=\\{v \\in \\{0,1\\}^c \\ \\ | \\ \\ \\mbox { the truth value of $ s$ according to $ v$ is $ 1 $ } \\}.\\ ] ]    summarizing sentences in @xmath329 describe subsets of @xmath335 and two sentences describe the same set if and only if they are equivalent .",
    "the power of the logical description of @xmath346 lies in the possibility of describing the same set in a variety of ways .",
    "for example the logical agent may be told that a subset of @xmath335 is described by a sentence @xmath333 , that another subset of @xmath335 is described by a sentence @xmath44 , and be asked to provide a sentence which describes the union of those sets .",
    "it will readily answer that @xmath349 is the sought after sentence . +",
    "it is natural to wonder if any logical meaning can be ascribed to the boolean algebra @xmath350 .",
    "although preliminary we venture an answer : assume the logical agent is told that a sentence @xmath351 describes an unknown subset of @xmath335 with probability @xmath352 for @xmath353 , and that a sentence @xmath354 describes another unknown subset of @xmath335 with probability @xmath355 for @xmath356 if asked to find a sentence that describes the union of those subsets the logical agent will answer : the sentence @xmath357 describes the union of the unknown sets with probability @xmath358 this is the only consistent answer with the product rules on @xmath350 which is given by @xmath359)\\cup ( \\sum_{j=1}^{m}q_{j}[t_j ] )   = \\sum_{i=1,j=1}^{n , m}p_{i}q_{j}[s_i \\vee t_j].\\ ] ]    this probabilistic interpretation applies as well to the boolean algebra @xmath90 .",
    "let @xmath360 and @xmath361 be a couple of vectors in @xmath90 given by @xmath362 assume that the coefficients of @xmath360 and @xmath361 , respectively , are positive and add to one .",
    "this allow us to think that @xmath363 represents the probability that the unknown subset @xmath360 of @xmath3 be equal to @xmath142 .",
    "similarly @xmath364 represents the probability that @xmath361 be equal to @xmath143 . under this conditions we have that    * the probability that @xmath365 be equal to @xmath366 is given by @xmath367 . *",
    "the probability that @xmath368 be equal to @xmath366 is given by @xmath369 .",
    "* the probability that @xmath370 be equal to @xmath142 is @xmath371 .",
    "finally we invite the reader to take another look at the structural coefficients of the algebras @xmath247>$ ] and @xmath248>^{\\otimes 3}/\\mathbb{z}_3 $ ] given in section [ spoba ] and check that they are indeed consistent with the probabilistic interpretation just outlined ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we define boolean algebras in the linear context and study its symmetric powers . we give explicit formulae for products in symmetric boolean algebras of various dimensions . </S>",
    "<S> we formulate symmetric forms of the inclusion - exclusion principle . </S>"
  ]
}
